label: A_aP24_2_12i-001
title: Low Temperature ``White'' Phosphorous Structure
comments:
Phosphorus is found in at least three forms: \begin{itemize} \item \href{current_web_home_dir/A_oC8_64_f-002}{Black phosphorus, {\em Strukturbericht} $A17$}, \item \href{current_web_home_dir/A_mP84_13_21g-001}{Monoclinic Hittorf's phosphorus}, and \item \href{current_web_home_dir/A_aP24_2_12i-001}{Low temperature triclinic ``white'' phosphorus}, stable below 197K. (this structure) \end{itemize} ~ \vspace{-.25in} 
 We use the data taken at 162K. 
 The P$_{4}$ molecules exhibit considerable rigid-body motion, both rotational and translational (Simon, 1987). 
 There is considerable disagreement about the name of this structure.  Most authors refer to it as $\beta$-white phosphorous, but (Donohue, 1982) refers to it as $\alpha$-white phosphorous.  Other authors refer to this as yellow phosphorous.  Simply referring to this as low temperature phosphorous seems the easiest way to avoid confusion.
